values:
Sheesh...  It's been months since I last updated this thing.  A lot has happened, but I'll try to keep it short and sweet =)

First off, I got a full time job at the museum!  I was offered the Visitor Services Associate position on July 1st, and have been keeping myself extremely busy ever since.  It would take me at least a day to write about everything I've been up to, but some high lights are seeing the Ecumenical Patriarch of the Orthodox Church and teaching tour groups about Netherlandish art from the 16th century.  

Second off, I had an incredible summer.  My friends from Fordham and I have spent a lot of time together, between going on road trips to Connecticut and Long Island for grad/birthday parties, and chillin in the City.  I am positively certain that these people will be my friends for life =)

Third off, I am happily in a relationship =)  My boyfriend Pete and I have been officially dating for a month now, and he is absolutely incredible.  We met at the end of September at the expense of an online dating site =P  I never thought I'd turn to one of those, but I took the plunge after hearing about a free site.  I pretty much said, "Hey, I got nothing to lose," and am happy I swallowed my pride and created a profile.  We are two peas in a pod, and have sooooo much in common.  Our personalities click, and we have the best of times together.  He met my best friend Steve a few weeks ago, and they get along great.  Pete also met my Fordham friends last night, and we had such an amazing time together.  I can't get over how well everyone got along, and it was especially nice hearing Tynan say, "You two are gonna be great together."

I am in a very happy place in my life, despite some of the normal misgivings I have to deal with.  Regardless, I have a great job, amazing friends, and an incredible boyfriend.  What more could a girl ask for?

It's been quite some time since I've updated this thing.  The semester is going rather well, but I still can't fathom the fact that I won't be coming back in the fall.  Fordham is my home (literally and figuratively) and I don't know how I can accept the fact that I won't see my friends as often as I do now.  One of my roommates and I went out for dinner last night, and we were talking about how we feel like our true selves around our friends at school.  Leaving that comfort is going to be very strange once we get those diplomas.  I never truly realized how much Fordham has given me.  Yeah, the administration can be quite fucked up at times, but I really do love this school.  I've met quite incredible people (with the exception of a few, but that's okay), and have learned so much about myself.  I've experienced so much, and through those good times, as well as bad times, I've been able to see how I react and relate to situations.  I'm proud to say that I've been a strong person throughout it all, and I'm so lucky to have amazing friends to be there with me through thick and thin.

Speaking of which, I've been going through a pretty rough week.  My family and I had to move out of our apartment in my grandma's house, and moved downstairs.  We sold the house, and the new homeowner is allowing us to stay and pay rent.  He's not going to live there, but owns it as an investment, and plans on renting out the upstairs apartment to someone else.  It's been so stressful because we were only given a week's notice to move everything out.  Granted, all we had to do was move things down one flight of stairs, one week is not enough time to prepare and make room for everything.  We've had to sacrifice so much, and it's so hard to fathom people other than my family living under the same roof.  

My friends have been great through this whole process.  Tynan and his roommate Clint came over and helped move my furniture on Thursday.  Though they weren't over long, they still did a lot of work, which I'm most grateful for.  My roommate Sara came over yesterday, and helped me rearrange my furniture because things were not fitting properly.  I had a vision and finally solved the puzzle (thank God cause that's been bothering me for days now).  I had to get rid of my desk and shelf that holds my records and stereo, and I hate that I lost these two articles of furniture because I don't know where I can store these things now.  

It's going to be a hard transition for me once I go home for Spring Break.  Unlike everyone else, I have not slept in my new room yet, and it's going to be so weird once I do.  I just can't believe we got to this point.  We had everything made for us, but my grandma had to piss it all in the wind.  I'm angry that this had to happen, and I wish things could have turned out differently.  Not to mention, I can see this is truly affecting my mother.  She looks sicker and sicker every time I see her.  She recently found out that her left breast is now infected, as well as her under arm on the right side of her body.  She has to undergo another biopsy (which will be some time this week) so they can remove the cancerous cells.  This has got to be her 4th or 5th surgery by now, and I don't know how much more she can take.  Just when her hair was starting to grow back, she had to start getting chemo again.  She was so excited that her natural hair was coming back, but of course, fate had to steal any ounce of happiness away from her.  

I truly have a bad feeling about my mother's health, and I don't think she has much time left.  I sound horrible for saying that, and I'm not a doctor, but I can just tell that she's sick of being sick.  I can't say that I blame her for giving up because who wants to wake up every morning, only leaving the house to see doctors.  It's such a damn shame that this has to happen to her.  She is one of the sweetest people I know, and she doesn't deserve any of this.  Of course, no one deserves to be sick, but why do bad things always happen to good people?  Of course, I'm angry and saddened over all of this, but I can't blame any of this on anyone or anything, especially God.  My grandmother (though I've always questioned her religious beliefs) had told me that she's very angry with Him.  I know that she, too, is going through a lot, but blaming it on God isn't the answer.  Instead, having faith in God is the only true remedy.  Keeping a positive attitude, too, is also key.  I just hope that when my mother does go to Heaven, we will all be at peace and won't feel that anger and frustration any more.  Of course, I don't want to lose my mother, but the reality of this situation is that this disease is going to kill her.  Being angry is not going to bring her back.  At least I know that I will feel relief knowing that she won't have to suffer anymore.  

I know I don't always show it, but all of this stuff is quite upsetting.  It's been getting to me a lot, especially this week, but I'm trying not to dwell on it so much.  Everyone knows me for always having a positive outlook on life, as well as being loud and cheery all the time.  Heck, most people wouldn't even know I'm going through as much as I am because of the way I carry myself.  I figure, displaying anger and frustration isn't going to make the situation any better.  At least being bubbly helps me get through the day and not worry about everything so much.  

Again, I can't say it enough how grateful I am for having my friends there for me.  I'm glad that Tynan came over the other day because he finally saw what I have to go through first-hand.  Yeah, simply telling him about what's going on keeps him informed, but actually witnessing it really allows it to settle in.  He told me that he truly feels sorry for me.  It's weird, I am glad that he cares enough to say that, but at the same time, I don't want his pity.  As frustrating as everything is, I have to accept it for what it's worth and just take it one day at a time.  I know I'm a strong person, and I can get through this.  Granted, I do get upset over it from time to time, but at least I know I have my friends' shoulders to cry on.

Being I have free time at work, I guess it doesn't hurt to update this thing again.  I think I officially broke a record or something.  It's quite rare seeing me write here as frequently as I have lol.  

I went out with Katrina and Jackie after work last evening.  I wasn't sure how the evening was going to pan out, nor know how the vibe was going to be.  I touched on this with the girls as we were talking over a drink.  I feel that there is a slight disconnect among our friends at home.  Don't get me wrong, we all get along well when we see one another, but things don't feel the way as they used to.  We're not as close as we all used to be, and I often times feel when we try to be open about certain things, some people can get a little judgmental or not look at things in the context of the whole picture.  They nit-pick without fully understanding the depth of the situation, if you will.  For instance, my relationship with Tynan was, and has been under such scrutiny among certain friends from home.  They don't understand that he and I are best friends.  Yes, two of my friends from home got a very bad first impression of him, but that doesn't give them the right to pass judgment on my friendship with him.  I know they are looking out for me emotionally because I do have feelings for him, but that doesn't give them the right to claim that he uses me and what not.  Yes, I do a lot for him, but that doesn't mean that my efforts do not go unnoticed.  

I try to refrain from talking about him as much as possible when at home because I feel like I'm walking on eggshells.  I know if I say something, it may instigate a conversation I don't want to get involved in.  

Such discussions about him are not the only things that trouble me while at home.  Jenn confronted me the other day, claiming that I seem "bored" when I'm out with her and our other friends.  I don't think it's fair to make such a claim, but I'll admit that I sometimes feel like we don't have much in common anymore, and it's hard to make conversation.  I asked her if she gets offended when I invite my local Fordham friends out, and she said that she likes them, but they can be a part of the problem (in the sense that I pay more attention to them, rather than she and our other friends).  That made me feel really bad because I never meant for that to happen.  My rational was, "Hey, we're on break, and it would be nice to introduce my friends from home to my friends from Fordham.  Heck, they're in the area, and I don't think they're busy doing anything.  Might as well invite them, too!"  I don't know why I'm necessarily being put on the chopping block for this cause I'm not the only one who has invited friends from their designated schools to meet the home team, if you will.  It's such a shame that they feel I don't give them adequate "Bern time."

I suppose this situation is something I need to contemplate, because I was also told that it seems like I make phone calls a lot when I'm in their company.  I'll be honest, though.  I don't feel like I do that a lot, but it's one more thing I was called out on.  I hate to say this, but I feel like I'm being attacked, but I know I shouldn't feel that way.  I know they're only voicing their concerns, but is it a crime for being a social butterfly?  I guess I do invite other people because my idea of a good time doesn't consist of hearing my friends make petty comments about what some girl is wearing, or how some guy needs to change his outfit.  When I go out, I want to go out to have a good time, make good conversation, and create laughter.  I don't want to listen to banter about how the girls in the corner are dressed like sluts, and that if that guy in that corner doesn't talk to me, he's an ass.  

Taking my friends from school out of this equation, I feel the problem is a little bit deeper than what's really on the surface.  Being we've all gone our own separate ways, we haven't had the opportunity to be as close as we used to be.  The time and distance that kept us apart has weakened some of our relationships, but I also think it's also allowed us to grow, in a sense.  I'm going to be quite frank here.  Up until college, I feel like I have been stuck in the shadow of one of my friends.  We were best friends since childhood, but once we went our separate ways, I finally felt like I was my own person.  I could do what I want, make my own decisions...I finally felt independent.  I was finally able to make my own friends, something I hadn't done in years.  I often times felt that I made friends with her friends because she was much more involved and outgoing, and it was easier for me to meet people that way.  Being out there on my own opened my eyes to new experiences and new people.  In making such friendships, I've realized that I've connected with a few other people who actually understand me much better than she does.  I'll confide in them more openly and freely before I bring certain news to her.  However, I don't know if she truly believes that we're still the best of buds that we were in high school.

One more thing I want to touch on.  I don't necessarily appreciate it when people I was never that close to think they can pass judgment on me, claiming that they really know what's going on.  If I never confided in you in high school, what makes you think we're that tight in college?  Yes, people's relationships can change in time.  Trust me, I've had it happen with a few girls from high school who I tend to talk to/see more often now than I did then.  But if we barely spoke then, and we only speak the two times that we see each other throughout the year, I think you should keep your thoughts and opinions to yourself.  

I never meant for this entry to turn into this massive venting session, but it's something that has been on my mind for some time now.  I really think that people are in denial about their relationships with others, and they can't admit it to themselves.  People change, they grow up.  The things that mattered to us in the past don't necessarily hold true anymore.  Oh, and by no means do I dislike anyone; please, don't get that impression.  I just feel that people need to recognize that certain friendships have changed, and living in the past isn't a wise thing to do.  Yes, we can reflect on the past, and talk about the past, but don't assume that all of the friendships from back in the day necessarily remain the same.

I feel like updating again =P  I've been sitting here at work reading old LJ entries.  I tend to do that when I work alone.  I couldn't help but feel a sense of nostalgia, but at the same time, I noticed how funny it is how certain things haven't changed.  Granted, the entries range from a year-and-a-half to a year ago, it feels like it's been longer than that.  Reading about sophomore year takes me back to a slightly different place, and I'm sure other college students can attest to that.  I find it rather funny how my feelings for a certain classmate ::cough cough:: Tynan ::cough cough:: remain the same, if not stronger, while feelings for a certain Marine ::cough cough:: Gonz ::cough cough:: don't even exist anymore.  The amount of stress I endured (and continue to endure) over these two is quite hysterical.  I can't help but laugh at some of the old entries I wrote.  The things I wrote about Tynan still hold true--two friends like each other a little more than friends, but can't be together because the guy doesn't want a girlfriend...Story of my life.  

The intensity I felt for Gonz, though, was incredible, and it sometimes surprises me how hard I fell for the guy.  It's unfortunate that our friendship didn't revert to the way it was prior to his  moving to California, but letting go of my feelings for him and that false sense of hope was the best thing I could do for myself.  

I feel like a much stronger person since letting go of Gonz, though, I sometimes feel weak due to my feelings for Tynan.  Regardless, I at least have the comfort of knowing that no matter what, we're still friends.  He's my best friend, and I do not lie when I say he knows everything about me.  Shit, he knows me so well, he understands my feelings and emotions even before I realize them!  (Not even joking)  If there's anyone I want to be with at this time in my life, it's him, but it's not likely to happen.  We've had this conversation so many times until we're blue in the face (and I run out of tears =P).  I can't imagine my life without him, and the thought of not seeing him after we graduate brings me to tears (I kid you not).  I spend most of my free time with him, and making that transition to not seeing him at all truly upsets me.  I know he knows how much he means to me;  I don't even have to say it.  There have been countless times I'd give him a hug and proceed to leave his room, and have him call out and say, "I know you love me."  As much as I don't want to admit it, that's the absolute truth.

I've been home for close to a week now, and it's a shame to say that I haven't seen anyone yet.  Hell, I barely left the house since I've been back.  I couldn't take sitting indoors anymore, so I decided to take the bus to Central Ave. last evening.  I wound up buying this really nice blanket with the gift card my boss gave me.  I would've stayed out longer, but I had to make it back in time to catch the last bus.  Once I graduate, I'm making a promise to myself to take driving classes.  I can't deal with traveling by public transportation anymore, and I'm definitely not banking on anyone teaching me how to drive.  I've waited long enough...It's time I learn and get my own set of wheels.

I've been thinking about what I should do for New Year's Eve.  Jenn invited me to a club, but it's too expensive.  I'd rather sit at home and drink a cheap bottle of wine, than spend $150 for an open bar and cocktail weenies.  Some guy who graduated from Fordham two years ago invited me to a party at his place.  I don't really know him, so I don't think I'll go.  However, my roommate is friends with him, and she's considering going.  I'll have to see.  But as of now, I'm also invited to a party in Danbury, which seems like the most probable place I'll ring in the New Year.  If anyone has any other ideas, let me know =P

Okay, so I'm at work right now, and I'm flying solo today (and tomorrow, too).  I had a feeling we'd have a lot of people come in.  One of the guards thought it'd be a slow day, but we've been closed for two days now.  I can't tell if it's mostly natives or tourists, but either way, we're getting a pretty good head count--it's the Christmas season, family is in town, tourists are visiting, the weather is fairly nice...Shit, I hope people don't come around 5:15/5:30 cause I hope to be out of here by then.  I gotta make it back to Bronxville in time to catch the last bus.  See, this is what I'm fucking talking about--Public transportation blows because I can't even stay at work long enough without having to worry about bus schedules...Ugh!

I've officially been on Christmas break since 3:30 Tuesday afternoon, but haven't gone home yet.  It's nice relaxing around the apartment, chilling with my friends.  Tynan and I made a turkey dinner for everyone on Wednesday night.  With the help of Sara and Joe, we put together a meal that could feed an army lol.  On Thursday, I played the role of Betty Crocker, and made brownies and a cake for Tynan's birthday.  Though it was technically on Friday, I made dessert ahead of time so most of his roommates could come over before they went home for break.  We did, however, go out to celebrate on Friday.  Despite having another tear-jerking heart-to-heart converstation earlier that night, I put my game face on and wound up enjoying myself for the rest of the evening.  We went to one of the local bars, and danced the night away.  Unfortunately, a certain someone got kicked out because he accidentally punched the bouncer, so we made our way back to Walsh.  Needless-to-say, he almost got arrested on the treck back for public urination...can't take this kid anywhere =P  Regardless, I still had an awesome time. 

He left early yesterday morning, and I walked him to the elevator to say goodbye.  Soon after, one of my roommates left, but she'll be back tomorrow for an exam.  So my roommate, Sara, and I pretty much spent the whole day together.  She made me dinner, and then we went out to see what people were up to.  The bar scene was so unusual, though.  Barely any Fordham students were out, and it was infested with former Fordham Prep students, guidos, and underage kids from Yorktown.  Petty fights broke out: a few at Mugz's, and another at Ziggy's (which required the cops to come and break it up).  Hell, I almost got into a fight with some asshole from the Prep because he threw a beer cup across the bar, and hit me.  I went up to him and cursed him out cause he better watch what the fuck he's doing.  What nonsense...  These fucking kids should leave their bullshit at home, or simply not go out at all. 

Other than that, I'm at work at the moment.  I overslept, but still managed to get here by 10 (thank the Lord).  I was hoping that I'd get a call saying we'll be closed due to the weather, but of course, that was wishful thinking.  Once I get home, I'll probably have dinner, and start packing.  I'm gonna go home tomorrow, and may be back at school by January 5th (I have yet to decide).  Being I have work in the City, it's easier to commute from the Bronx, as opposed to making the horrific commute from Yonkers.  We'll see what happens.

Although we've never been together as a couple, it feels like we broke up last night.  We decided that we cannot continue having the relationship that we have because it's making things too complicated.  I want more than a friendship, but he can't give that to me.  We pretty much laid everything on the table, and he said that he likes me a little more than a friend, but he can't be my boyfriend.  He just doesn't want that in his life right now.  It sucks because it's been this way for 2 years, and I can't get past him.  The more time we spend together, the more I want to be with him.  Everyone says it seems like we're dating, and that we should just make it official, but he can't make that commitment.  

He played this song for me as we were laying in bed together, claiming this is exactly how he feels.  Oh, how Johnny Cash has a way with words, I couldn't help but cry...

EDIT:  I started writing this entry on Thursday morning.  When I came home from work that day, he stopped by and was acting kinda strange.  He gave me a $10 Best Buy gift card (that he received for free with his purchase, might I add), then proceeded to admit that he wanted to buy me a DVD, but just didn't do it.  I asked him why he was being so nice, and he said that he felt bad about the night before.  He claimed that the vibe was off.  Since then, things feel as if nothing particularly changed from the time we had that conversation.  We've cooked each other dinner for the past two nights, hung out and watched tv...However, he did say something that really pissed me off last night.  He was talking to my roommate and his roommate about dating, and said that going to the movies is a bad idea.  So I chimed in by saying, "Yeah, it is, because you fall asleep."  Then he snapped and said, "Wait a minute, that wasn't a date."  We went to see a movie together about a month and a half ago, and he payed for me.  I took out my wallet and offered to pay him back, but then he said not to worry.  Soon after he said, "This is why I don't take girls out on dates--I'm cheap." Right before we walked into the theater, he told me to find us seats, and asked if I wanted anything from the snack bar.  Then once the movie was over, he hailed a cab for himself, and just before he got in, he gave me a kiss on the cheek, and went on his way.  Oh, and I can't forget the phone convo we had later that night.  I thanked him for taking me out, and he said, "Don't thank me.  I owed it to you."  

Call me crazy, but wouldn't statements and actions such as those imply that it was, indeed, a date?  I'll admit, as much as I want to think that it was one, I have to try to convince myself otherwise because I know he'd say something like that in front of our friends.  Why can't he just admit to himself (as well as others) that it's okay to take me out and call it a fucking date?  This kid stresses me out so much.  I need to take a vacation from him lol.

So, today is my 22nd birthday...

Yeah.

Woo.

I guess being I have to work, I'm not entirely excited.  Or perhaps I got the excitement out of my system when going out on Friday and Saturday.  

Or maybe it's something else...

I was hanging out with Tynan last night, and he was constantly talking about one of my roommates.  It caught me off guard cause he never, ever brings up her name as often as he did last night.  I noticed that they've been hanging out a lot lately, and I hate to admit this, but it's getting to me.  I've never had to compete with someone to get his attention.  For two years, it's always been just me and Tynan.  Now that we live down the hall from one another, my roommates have gotten to know him and his roomies.  At first, my roommates would only come over because I was there.  Now that they've gotten to know the guys, they no longer go to chase after me, but stop by to hang out with them.  I should be happy that everyone is getting along, but I can't help but feel jealous.  I miss hanging out with him one on one.  It erks me when we're hanging out, then someone else walks in the room mid-way in our conversation and stays in the room. 

But as far as last night went, something seemed different.  I couldn't help but get the feeling that Tynan is attracted to my roommate.  He offered to make me dinner, then right afterwards, he said I should ask my roomie if she wants some, too.  When I did ask her, she said no, and on 3 occassions, he told me to ask if she wanted any, despite my relaying her message of "no."  He made a few more remarks, and later in the evening, I just had it.  I said, "Well, you'be been talking about 'so and so' a lot tonight.  What's up with that?"  Then he said he just noticed that she's been down in the dumps as of late and just wanted to be nice.  Yeah, that's fine, but I can't help but think there's something a little deeper than that.  

I don't want to feel this way because it's so frustrating--I have strong feelings for my best friend, who may have feelings for my roommate.  How the hell am I supposed to deal with that?  I want someone I can't have because he doesn't feel the same way about me.  It's a kick in the stomach when he compares me to her, and says things like, "She took care of me when I was sick.  She made me a grilled cheese sandwich."  Yeah, well don't fucking forget who walked to the store to get you medicine, walked to another store to get you soup, cooked it, took your temperature multiple times, and tucked you into bed.  Shit, I do so much for this fucking kid, and the one thing that sticks out in his mind is the fact that my fucking roommate made him a grilled cheese sandwich on one fucking occassion!  Shit, I do so much for him practically every day!  

I need to calm down cause I know I'm overreacting a bit.  But it's so fucking hard dealing with emotions, especially when you know you can't do anything about them.  I wish I could've gotten over him years ago, but for some reason I simply can't.  And the fact that we spend so much time together only makes my feelings for him stronger.  As stupid as this sounds, he's not the perfect guy, and I don't even know why I like him.  But for some reason, I'm incredibly attracted to him (not just physically) and need him in my life.  I tell him everything, and I trust him.  But there are times when he can be such an ass, and I only want to punch him.  We definitely have a love/hate relationship, but it works.  Though we can get on each other's nerves at times, we still know how to pick up the pieces, and forget about our troubles the next day.  

But there is something I want to make clear, though.  I'm not holding myself back from meeting anyone else because of him.  People may think I do, but I don't.  In fact, I have dated other people despite liking him.  I know where Tynan stands as far as his feelings go about me. He's told me he likes me, but he can't be my boyfriend.  He doesn't want a girlfriend at this time in his life, and that's fine.  Thus, I know I can't bank on having a relationship with him.  But if I were to meet someone tonight who's the least bit interesting, I'll give that guy the time of day.  I just wish that I didn't have these feelings for him anymore, and can have a normal friendship with him.

If it does turn out that Tynan likes my roommate, I don't know how I can deal with that.  I know I'll get incredibly upset, and it's going to make things awkward for people.  Fuck...I wish I could swallow a pill that will clear me up of this love sickness I have.

Though it isn't until Wednesday, I think it's safe to say that my 22nd birthday is the best one thus far. I went out Friday evening with a group of friends from school, and it was truly a pleasant experience--I couldn't wipe the smile off my face. We made our way to Puglia Ristorante, my favorite Italian restaurant, then enjoyed a comedy show at the Laugh Lounge. Though some people couldn't attend, I had a wonderful time, and am truly grateful to all that showed up. They treated me to a wonderful dinner, beautiful toasts, and countless laughs. I can't stop looking at the pictures because it was such an incredible night. Before I went out again last evening, my friend Tynan gave me a kiss on the cheek and said, "Thank you for inviting me. I had a great time." That was truly the icing on the cake. You see, he tends to spend his weekends with friends outside of college, and keeps his school friends separate from his other friends. The fact that he gave up his Friday night to celebrate my birthday means so much to me. He doesn't like to try new things, but he swallowed his pride and went to the comedy club. After every joke, I couldn't help but look at him because I could tell he was having a great time--he was laughing harder than most of us. Nothing can shake off that feeling of satisfaction. He's my best friend at Fordham, and I want to spend as much time with him before we graduate. I don't know how things will be once school is over, but I know I'm going to miss him terribly. Aside from that, two of my roommates and I went out to dinner with our friends Gina and Alyssa last night. We celebrated my birthday again by having a self-proclaimed "Girls' Night." Though the wait at Blockheads was a bit annoying, the food was great and the margaritas were fantastic. I drank mine a little too fast and felt it just as dinner was served lol. We went to our friend's apartment afterwards, then went back to mine about an hour later. Gina and my friend Eric felt the need to make waffles, so they played Better Crocker for a lil while lol. All in all, I had a wonderful weekend, and am truly blessed to have the friends that I have here at Fordham. Just when I thought he was out of my life for good, he contacted me.  What are the odds of that?  I received a text message from an unfamiliar phone number last Sunday, and after reading it a second time, I knew it was him.  I played dumb and asked who it was, and he revealed his identity.  We spoke on the phone for about half-an-hour or so, and he genuinely sounded interested in how I'm doing.  I, on the other hand, didn't sound as excited because I was in a state of shock.  I couldn't believe he had the audacity to contact me, seeing how he ignored me the last time he was home.  I wanted to confront him about that, but the timing wasn't right.  He was in a bus with a bunch of Marines, and I didn't feel comfortable having that type of conversation while he didn't have any privacy.    

He told me he'll be home by the end of the month, but he didn't outright ask to make plans (nor did I).  I learned my lesson from years past, and I'm not going to chase after him anymore.  If he wants to see me, he can pick up the phone and call.  But I'm not holding my breath.  He always sets me up for disappointment, and I know better not to allow that to happen again.  For instance, as we were getting off the phone the other night, he asked what I'd be doing the following evening.  I told him I had class until 9, and he said he'd give me a call around that time.  Low and behold, no word from him since he mentioned that.  Oh well...  The ball is in his court now, and I'm merely standing on the sidelines.

As the semester rolls on, I can't help but get ansy about graduation.  Though it is months away, I can't help but feel that time is going by so quickly.  The thought of graduating is bitter-sweet.  Yes, I'll finally be on my way to attaining a career in the so-called "real world," but the thing I'll miss most is leaving all of my friends behind.  Of course, it's all a part of growing up, as they say, but it's such a hard reality to face.  The people I've grown close to within the past four years are some of the most incredible people I've ever met.  I can't help but get teary-eyed every time I think about saying that last goodbye to my best friend here.  He and I have had a roller coaster of a friendship, but despite all of our bickering, we always know how to kiss and make up.  I believe that we will remain friends after college, but I don't know how often we'd be able to see each other.  That's something I'm going to have a difficult time with because we see each other practically every day.  Being we live down the hall from one another, it's so easy to spend time together.  Gosh, it will be a hard reality not being able to see him whenever I want once we're out of here.

I know most of my recent entries seem to focus on the theme of graduation, but it's something that's frequently on my mind.  If I could turn back the hands of time and re-live all of this, I would, but I don't think I'd change any of it.  Yes, I have gone through some of the worst things imaginable, but it would be selfish of me to say I'd change any of it; if it weren't for such events, I wouldn't be the person I am today.  We shouldn't have any regrets, but learn from our mistakes and misfortunes.    

P.S.  YES WE CAN!  Mad kudos to Barack Obama.  This is truly a remarkable day in history!

So, I have some great news that I'd like to share with all of you.  A couple of weeks ago, Ute, the General Manager at the Museum of Biblical Art, stopped by.  She's on maternity leave at the moment, but she likes to come in at least once a week to see how things are going.  I stopped by her office to see what she thought of the binders I put together for her.  She absolutely loved them!  We walked over to the filing cabinet so I could show her the additional projects I worked on, and she was very impressed.  She and I stood outside of my office, and she said, "We've had a great bunch of interns this summer.  Trust me, I've seen a lot come and go, but you girls are fantastic.  And I gotta say, you especially."  That was a total ego booster, and I'm ecstatic that she singled me out like that.  

Last Wednesday, I was walking out of my office, and I heard Ute talking about me with two of my co-workers, Michelle and Debbie.  So, I walked over because I wanted to know what was going on.  Michelle saw me approaching, and she said, "Oh, we were just talking about you."  Then I replied, "So I've heard."  She then explained that the museum is receiving a lot of visitors due to the latest exhibition on display, and they could really use the help in Visiting Services.  She knew I am looking for a weekend job during the school year, and asked if I'd like to officially join the MOBIA staff.  Ute then explained that she is pleased with my work, and would love for me to join their team as a part-time worker.  In the meantime, Debbie was sitting in her cubicle whispering, "TAKE THE JOB, TAKE THE JOB!"  I was taken aback, and quite thrilled that they offered me a job.  I asked how much they'd pay an hour, and Ute said $10 an hour.  They then said, "Take your time making your decision," but I replied, "I think I made it already.  I'll take the job!"  

I start training on Monday, which is good considering the museum is closed on Mondays.  I am very excited and quite thrilled that they asked me.  I recently applied for a job at the school book store.  I heard it's not the best job, and I only applied there cause I really could use the money.  Now that I was offered this job at the museum, I have a better chance at seeking other positions in the museum field, whether at MOBIA or elsewhere.

In other news, I went to my friend's "wedding" last Friday night at Kelly's Pub, aka Cassie's.  I went with my friend Katrina, and the night started off on the wrong foot when the bartender gave Kat a hard time for being underage.  As Kat and I were trying to come up with a plan of action, this guy came outside to have a cigarette.  Moments earlier, I noticed that he was standing with Daren, the "groom," so I asked him if he knows the bartender.  He told us not to worry, and if anything, he'd get us drinks at the bar.  Needless to say, I introduced myself to him, and he told us his name is Kevin.  After chit-chatting for a minute or so, we walked back inside, and he kinda shielded us until we made our way to the back.  He then walked over with his friend Steve, the bagpiper.  We started talking as they were playing darts.  As the night progressed, we talked a bit more, but not too much.  Once the wedding was over, I stood outside the bar with him for a few minutes.  He said that Kat and I seemed like cool people, and he'd like to hang out with us again.  We exchanged numbers and called it an evening. 

The next morning, I woke up to an unknown phone call, and a text message.  It was Kevin.  He and I sent texts to one another early in the morning, then he asked if I would like to go out with him some time for dinner and a movie.  He then said that I looked "beautiful" the night before, and that I "caught his eye."  ::blush::  

We went out last night, and I could tell from the start that he was nervous.  I honestly felt like I was on a date during high school, but it was a very endearing moment.  We were pressed for time, so we got a slice of pizza.  We then headed down Central Ave. to see "Mirrors."  Unfortunately, the movie was sold out, so we opted to see "Star Wars: Clone Wars" at United Artist instead.  It was just the two of us in this huge theater, until some old man came strolling in.  The movie was alright.  I think George Clooney, I mean George Lucas hit his peak a long time ago.  He needs to chill out cause this animated stuff is simply going to put a damper on the awesome work he's produced in the past. 

Besides that, Kevin and I went back to his apartment after the movie and watched the Olympics.  He has a cute cat named Sam, and he's quite friendly.  We were playing with him for awhile, and sat on his awesome reclining couch.  The most entertaining thing happened next when he yawned, stretched out his arms, and wrapped one around my shoulders.  I couldn't help myself and said, "smooth move."  Then he said, "Sorry, I've been wanting to do that all night.  That guy in the theater totally ruined my game.  Plus, I'm really nervous, too.  I think I'll even be like this when I'm 40."  So I told him I could tell that he was nervous, and not to worry.  He eventually leaned in to give me a kiss (and asked if it was alright), but I stopped him because I don't want to rush into anything too fast.  I honestly felt like I broke his heart.  So he went to move his arm, and I said that we could still sit like that.  I just didn't want to kiss him yet because I want to get to know him better.  Oh, before that he said, "You're so beautiful...you have beautiful eyes...I think you are an awesome person..."  Needless to say, I was rather flattered by those compliments.  He seems like a really sweet guy, and I'm glad that we went out last night.  I definitely would like to see him again.

He's out of my life...I deleted his number and screen name, and de-friended him on MySpace and Facebook.  I am done.  I am through with the stress and frustration of wanting to know if he truly cares.  He clearly doesn't.  

I would write more about this, and even include pieces of a document I've been writing that was originally meant to be this entry, but I decided not to.  It's senseless.  I can vent until I am blue in the face, but nothing I say, type, or express would even matter at this point.  What's done is done...I am through with him.  I have given up on our friendship because it is clear to me that he has given up on it a long time ago.  

I will say this--Despite how I feel right now, I do hope that you make it through Iraq safe and sound.  I do not know if our paths will ever cross again, but if they don't, I hope you have a good life, and it was nice knowing you...Good bye.

I feel like this suddenly fell on me like a ton of bricks...He's going to Iraq.

Just when I thought I was over him, my heart won't allow me to.  I've put my best foot forward, I opened myself up to meeting other guys.  However, he's always in the back of my mind.  Regardless of how I feel, he doesn't feel the same way about me, so it should be easy for me to get over him, right?  Wrong...I've been battling this for years now, and the feelings just won't go away.  My friends often times get frustrated with me because they don't want to see me get hurt again.  Hell, they hate it when they see me wear this charm around my neck.  But they just don't get it.  Regardless of the feelings I still harbor, I wear this necklace as a testament to our friendship, and I told  him that the day I gave him the other half.  We've both been through a lot, and we've been there for one another to help pick up the pieces.  Recently, I've been going through something, and he's the one person who truly helped me get back in gear, and keep a positive outlook on life.  Though he doesn't open up as elaborately as I do, he still tells me enough to know what's going on, and I try as best as I can to be there and support him no matter what.  I believe it's in God's Hands if he and I were to be together someday, but despite what life may throw at us, I'll do anything to protect and continue my friendship with him.   

We've been talking to each other a lot more as of late, and I'm happy to say that it feels like old times once again.  I was looking forward to potentially seeing him at some point this summer, but then he told me the truth.  He was planning on coming home in August.  Instead, he's being deployed that month.  He'll be gone for a year, and he's rather excited to go.  I know how passionate he is about serving this country, and I admire that.  At the same time, though, it's only natural to feel pessimistic about the fact that he's going to war.  Anything can happen, and I'll be damned if something does...

I was laying in bed for a good thirty minutes or so, but I can't sleep.  I can't help but think about things, and what I would like to say to him before he gets shipped out.  I play the conversation in my mind over and over again, and I can't help but be brought to tears.  I'd give anything just to see him one last time.  We did see one another last summer, but things didn't feel right to me.  It's hard for me to explain it, but things seemed rather off.  But I'll never forget that last hug we shared moments before he stepped into his car.  Though he mentioned he wanted to see me one more time during his stay, I knew it was going to be the last time I'd see him before he went back to training.  It was a strong hug, a long hug.  And the kiss on the cheek was a sweet one.  If something were to potentially happen, I'd be content with that being the last memory we shared together.  However, I can't help but sound selfish right now because I would like to see him one last time.  Unfortunately, he admitted that's probably not possible.  I'd give anything for one last hug, one last kiss on the cheek... 

I hate sounding so morbid and pessimistic right now.  I should be more optimistic and display great support for him.  I'll be honest, I wasn't too enthused when he admitted to using my name and address as a reference on his recruitment form.  That left a sour taste in my mouth, as they say, and I just didn't have such a good feeling about it.  I'm rather passive, and do not agree with this war.  It sucks knowing that someone I truly and deeply care for will be going there, potentially putting his life on the line.  As much as I want to be optimistic that he'll come home safe and sound, this horrible feeling resides in the pit of my gut.  I'll tell ya, it's not a pleasant feeling, and I wish it would go away.  I had a stream of dreams about it last night, one of which involved someone aiming a gun at his head.  I woke up feeling incredibly uneasy, and rather frightened.  

Once he's there, I know I'm going to have a rough time dealing with it.  My friend Matt went to Iraq, and I couldn't help but worry about him. A remarkable woman is no longer with us.  My great grandmother, Nanny, lived a long, healthy life.  She was born on December 20, 1913, the first child of an Italian family of immigrants.  When growing up, she learned Italian and English to help her family adjust to American life.  Her father died when she was young, and she had to help her mother raise her younger brothers and sisters.  She later married, and had 4 children of her own--James, Phyllis, Marie, and Salvatore.  

Growing up, I considered Nanny my third mother--my first two were my mom and my grandma.  Being my father wasn't around much, these three women raised my sister, my brother, and myself.  I'll never forget the countless times Nanny would babysit us, and we'd play cards for hours on end.  I'll never forget the weekends when I slept over my grandma's house, and made "deliveries" to Nanny after my grandfather went grocery shopping.  She'd always give me the change she had on her bureau as a tip.  I'll never forget the times she used to dance around in her pjs and slippers (a woman in her late 80s, then) doing the Charleston!  I'll never forget how she adored Frank Sinatra, and would sing parts of his songs from time to time.  I'll never forget the stories she used to tell, and how she made sure she watched the local news every night.  I'll never forget how I'd sit next to her at the table every Thanksgiving and Christmas.  She'd sit on my left, and I'd help her cut her food from time to time.  As gross as this may sound, I'll never forget the way she used to play with her dentures.  As a child, I used to hear her clicking something in her mouth, then I once saw her teeth come out ever so slightly!  I was so scared because I didn't realize that she had false teeth lol.  I'll also never forget the times she'd help me with the annual Penny Pool (if you went to Victory, you'd know what I'm talking about).  She'd collect so many pennies every year, and donate them to the cause.  I'll also never forget how she'd always have to stand in the front when we took family pictures because she was the shortest out of everyone.  She was a cute, little, old lady that everyone adored.  I'll never forget how she'd wait by the door until we came home.  She'd stand there for ten minutes or so, go into another room, then stand by the door again.  I'll never forget how religious she was.  She'd pray every day, and make references to Mother Cabrini (her favorite saint) all of the time.  She'd even give my  family members religious tokens and trinkets all of the time--signs of her love and affection, and symbols to remember her by.  I have all of the small statues she gave me on top of a shelf in my room.  I will never part with them because they mean so much to me.  

She was in a nursing home for a little over a year.  Weeks prior to getting sick, I noticed a change in her attitude, and it often times made me upset.  One of the most upsetting conversations I've ever had was days prior to moving to school.  She claimed that she felt like she was withering away, and didn't want to continue living anymore.  I suppose all of the stress my grandmother gave her was getting to her, and it was finally wearing her down.  Keep in mind, she was 92 at the time, and healthy as an ox.  She never got sick, and wasn't plagued by any life altering illnesses.  Days later, I'll never forget saying goodbye to her as I was moving to Fordham.  She was standing at the doorway crying hysterically, and it broke my heart.  I told her I would be home soon, and that I'd see her in no time.  Unfortunately, the next time I saw her was about a month later, not at home, but in the nursing home.  She barely recognized me, and she didn't look like herself.  Her hair was white--it no longer consisted of the light brown dye job she used to get every couple of weeks.  She wasn't walking around, but was bedridden, and she barely made sense when she spoke.  Nanny had such a sharp mind before she got sick and was emitted to the nursing home.  She could tell you things from her childhood, that most people would expect she'd forget.  I couldn't bare to see her laying in that bed, and I chose not to see her anymore.  I'd always ask my family how she was doing whenever I'd call home, and unfortunately, the news was always the same--she barely made much progress.  I'd never hear that she was doing better with the possibility of her coming home, where she belonged.  

The last time I saw her was over the summer.  I decided to be strong, and see her.  She was laying in her bed, and claimed to be very cold (despite how warm it was outside).  I held her hand as my dad and grandma tried to give her water and make her feel comfortable.  She didn't make too much sense when she was talking, but I did hear her say she was "shaking like a leaf" and said my mom's name, Debbie, on numerous occasions.  I had a feeling that was going to be the last time I would see her, so I made sure I told her I love her.  I was almost overcome with emotion, but I held it back.  

I received a call from my mother this morning explaining how and when Nanny died.  It apparently happened yesterday, but my mom wanted to wait until today to tell me because she knew I was busy at the museum yesterday.  I wish I was told as soon as possible because I've always been concerned with my Nanny's health.  I'm not sure what the arrangements will be this week, but I know it's going to be a rough few days.  

Nanny, I'll always love you.  You've lived a long, strong life, and you've done so much to make so many people happy.  We'll never forget you.  Rest in peace.  12/20/1913-11/09/2007.
